channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: As toxic algae bloom afflicts sea lions and other marine animals, California wildlife center needs help
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The San Pedro-based Marine Mammal Care Center is in need of donations and volunteers as it combats an algae bloom that has killed or sickened more than 1,000 creatures.
item.content:encoded: The San Pedro-based Marine Mammal Care Center is in need of donations and volunteers as it combats an algae bloom that has killed or sickened more than 1,000 creatures.

media:content.media:description: San Pedro, CA - John Warner, chief executive officer of the Marine Mammal Care Center in San Pedro, looks at marine mammals recuperating at the center on Tuesday, June 20, 2023. More than 1,000 marine mammals have gotten sick or died this month due to toxic algae blooms along the coast of Southern California, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. June 20: in San Pedro on Tuesday, June 20, 2023 in San Pedro, CA. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Build less housing for cars and more for people. Two books on how the past can guide the future
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: Books for the housing future: Henry Grabar on how parking has wrecked cities and Frances Anderton on the residential designs that can help bring them back.
item.content:encoded: Books for the housing future: Henry Grabar on how parking has wrecked cities and Frances Anderton on the residential designs that can help bring them back.

media:content.media:description: June 20, 1955: After a transit strike brought thousands of additional cars to downtown Los Angeles parking lots, Sue Diane Blanke asks lot attendant Billy Funkhouser to get her car out. Impossible Funkhouser replied. This photo was published in the June 21, 1955 Los Angeles Times.

item.title: No glass and no payment: Former employee at Kanye West's school files lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Christian Martinez
item.description: A former employee at Kanye West's Donda Academy has filed a lawsuit alleging students were around exposed wires and windows without glass.
item.content:encoded: A former employee at Kanye West's Donda Academy has filed a lawsuit alleging students were around exposed wires and windows without glass.

media:content.media:description: SIMI VALLEY, CA-OCTOBER 27, 2022: Two notices from UPS, bottom, for packages they were trying to deliver, are left at the front gate entrance to Donde Academy on Tierra Rejada Rd. In Simi Valley that has been closed down. Donda Academy, a private school founded by the artist formerly known as Kanye West is shutting its doors in Simi Valley Thursday amid the ongoing backlash over the rapper's recent antisemitic comments. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Flier education: L.A. resident takes to the skies to attend UC Berkeley
item.dc:creator: Christian Martinez
item.description: Los Angeles resident Bill Zhou's typical door-to-door commute time was 4 to 5 hours each way, but the arduous travel schedule may have saved him thousands of dollars.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles resident Bill Zhou's typical door-to-door commute time was 4 to 5 hours each way, but the arduous travel schedule may have saved him thousands of dollars.

media:content.media:description: Bill Zhou completed a masters program at U.C. Berkeley by commuting almost daily from his home in Los Angeles.

item.title: L.A. County leaders vow to continue supporting migrant Angelenos based on State of Immigrants report
item.dc:creator: Mariana Duran
item.description: This year's report on the State of Immigrants in Los Angeles County showed that historic investments in resources have been made to immigrants but identifies areas that should be addressed to continue the momentum.
item.content:encoded: This year's report on the State of Immigrants in Los Angeles County showed that historic investments in resources have been made to immigrants but identifies areas that should be addressed to continue the momentum.

item.title: Fleeing rape, beatings and murder, migrant families find solace at shelter in Mexicali
item.dc:creator: Raul Roa
item.description: Migrant families fleeing their countries find solace at Mexicali's Cobina Posada Del Migrante, a shelter where they can stay while waiting for asylum.
item.content:encoded: Migrant families fleeing their countries find solace at Mexicali's Cobina Posada Del Migrante, a shelter where they can stay while waiting for asylum.

media:content.media:description: Because of problems with gangs, Genesis Abigail Flores Ceron, 20, left Honduras with her 3-year old son and arrived at Cobina Posada Del Migrante, where she reflects on her plight, in Mexicali, Mexico, on Saturday, June 24, 2023. Flores has been at the family shelter for almost 3 months waiting for her CNP One appointment.
media:content.media:credit: Raul Roa/Los Angeles Times en Espanol

item.title: Stanford will offer student-led class on Taylor Swift's storytelling 'through the eras'
item.dc:creator: Cari Spencer
item.description: Stanford University will offer a student-led class centered on Taylor Swift's songwriting and storytelling.
item.content:encoded: Stanford University will offer a student-led class centered on Taylor Swift's songwriting and storytelling.

media:content.media:description: Taylor Swift arrives at the 65th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday, Feb. 5, 2023, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP)

item.title: Veterinarian sues after Sheriff's Department dog dies in hot patrol cruiser
item.dc:creator: Keri Blakinger
item.description: Dr. Yolanda Cassidy says Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department officials fabricated and backdated a memo to cover up the 2020 death of a bomb-sniffing black Labrador named Spike who overheated in an unattended patrol car.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Yolanda Cassidy says Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department officials fabricated and backdated a memo to cover up the 2020 death of a bomb-sniffing black Labrador named Spike who overheated in an unattended patrol car.

media:content.media:description: #LASD SEB Tactical Bomb Techs and an accelerant detection canine, "Spike", searching for ignitable liquids at the scene of a suspected arson fire in Lake Los Angeles.

item.title: What California can learn about earthquake safety from Santa Monica
item.dc:creator: Sandhya Kambhampati, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: In a milestone for earthquake safety, more than half the 2,000 buildings that Santa Monica deemed as vulnerable have been retrofitted since a historic 2017 city law went into effect.
item.content:encoded: In a milestone for earthquake safety, more than half the 2,000 buildings that Santa Monica deemed as vulnerable have been retrofitted since a historic 2017 city law went into effect.

media:content.media:description: General overall aerial view of Santa Monica during a flight around Southern California on Saturday, October 5, 2019, in Los Angeles. (Brandon Sloter/Image of Sport via AP)

item.title: Column: Three's not a crowd. Meet the co-presidents of the union behind the hotel workers' strike
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: Ada Briceño, Susan Minoto and Kurt Petersen are co-presidents of Unite Here Local 11. It's believed to be the only such power-sharing arrangement in U.S. labor history.
item.content:encoded: Ada Briceño, Susan Minoto and Kurt Petersen are co-presidents of Unite Here Local 11. It's believed to be the only such power-sharing arrangement in U.S. labor history.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - Striking members of the Unite Here Local 11 hotel workers union make noise on the picket line outside the JW Marriott and Ritz-Carlton hotels in downtown Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023. The strike affects roughly 15,000 cooks, room attendants, dishwashers, servers, bellmen and front-desk agents at hotels in Los Angeles and Orange counties, July 03: in Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A payment overhaul is coming to California child care, along with a 20% raise for workers
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gold
item.description: Child-care providers reached a tentative agreement with the state to raise wages and change the way California calculates subsidies for low-income families.
item.content:encoded: Child-care providers reached a tentative agreement with the state to raise wages and change the way California calculates subsidies for low-income families.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - May 22: Adriana Lorenzo brings out bubbles for her students during play time at her Boyle Heights home day care center on Monday, May 22, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Have you seen a Humvee? The military would like it back, please
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Childs
item.description: The Santa Rosa-area CHP is looking for a Humvee stolen from a National Guard facility over the Fourth of July weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Santa Rosa-area CHP is looking for a Humvee stolen from a National Guard facility over the Fourth of July weekend.

media:content.media:description: The FBI is on the lookout for this California National Guard Humvee stolen from Bell.

item.title: Patt Morrison: Is California about to lose its most beautiful train ride?
item.dc:creator: Patt Morrison
item.description: The beauty of train trips used to be a key selling point. But with the Pacific Surfliner suffering the effects of climate change, safety and reliability may trump the pretty view.
item.content:encoded: The beauty of train trips used to be a key selling point. But with the Pacific Surfliner suffering the effects of climate change, safety and reliability may trump the pretty view.

media:content.media:description: The "Daylight" route was a 13-hour trip between Los Angeles and San Francisco and was sometimes called the "most beautiful train in America." This vintage postcard from Patt Morrison's collection shows a train on a coastline stretch of track.

item.title: To pay off a house outside of L.A., this hotel worker sleeps in her car four days a week
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: These hotel housekeepers are commuting long hours to their jobs in L.A. to afford houses they can one day pass down to their children.
item.content:encoded: These hotel housekeepers are commuting long hours to their jobs in L.A. to afford houses they can one day pass down to their children.

media:content.media:description: VICTORVILLE, CA - JULY 5, 2023: Gladis Avila still finds time to sweep her front porch after commuting five days a week from her home in Victorville to her job as a housekeeper at the W hotel in Hollywood on July 5, 2023 in Victorville, California. She lives in Victorville with her husband and three children.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mexican Mafia member who ran county jail rackets is killed in prison
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Michael Torres, a Mexican Mafia member who oversaw gangs in the San Fernando Valley and controlled drug and extortion rackets in the Los Angeles County jail system, was stabbed to death in prison.
item.content:encoded: Michael Torres, a Mexican Mafia member who oversaw gangs in the San Fernando Valley and controlled drug and extortion rackets in the Los Angeles County jail system, was stabbed to death in prison.

media:content.media:description: Michael Torres, a member of the Mexican Mafia, was stabbed to death on July 6, 2023 at California State Prison, Sacramento.
media:content.media:credit: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation

item.title: California officials join Texas sheriff in calling for federal investigation into DeSantis migrant flights
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Mays
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom and state Atty. Gen. Rob Bonta call for a federal investigation into migrants sent to Sacramento
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom and state Atty. Gen. Rob Bonta call for a federal investigation into migrants sent to Sacramento

media:content.media:description: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis speaks as he announces a proposal for Digital Bill of Rights, Wednesday, Feb. 15, 2023, at Palm Beach Atlantic University in West Palm Beach, Fla. (AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee)

item.title: Riverside council member arrested in second DUI case, weeks after previous conviction was dismissed
item.dc:creator: Terry Castleman
item.description: Riverside Councilmember Clarissa Cervantes was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence last weekend, just weeks after a conviction for a 2014 DUI was dismissed by a county judge.
item.content:encoded: Riverside Councilmember Clarissa Cervantes was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence last weekend, just weeks after a conviction for a 2014 DUI was dismissed by a county judge.

media:content.media:description: Booking photo of Riverside councilmember Clarissa Cervantes

item.title: California high court: Employers not responsible for COVID spread to workers' families
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Employers in California are not legally responsible for preventing the spread of COVID-19 from their employees to the employees' family members, the California Supreme Court ruled Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Employers in California are not legally responsible for preventing the spread of COVID-19 from their employees to the employees' family members, the California Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

media:content.media:description: SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 06: Registered Nurse Orlyn Grace (L) administers a COVID-19 booster vaccination to Jeanie Merriman (R) at a COVID-19 vaccination clinic on April 06, 2022 in San Rafael, California. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has authorized a second COVID-19 booster of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for people over 50 years old four months after their first booster. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: Princess Cruises ship hits San Francisco pier while docking
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Arredondo
item.description: Officials are assessing damage after the Ruby Princess cruise ship crashed into Pier 27 in San Francisco while docking Thursday morning.
item.content:encoded: Officials are assessing damage after the Ruby Princess cruise ship crashed into Pier 27 in San Francisco while docking Thursday morning.

media:content.media:description: A couple stands on a rear balcony of the Ruby Princess cruise ship while docked in San Francisco, Thursday, Jan. 6, 2022. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating a cruise ship that docked in San Francisco on Thursday after a dozen vaccinated passengers tested positive for coronavirus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: California Supt. of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond considers run for governor
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Mays
item.description: California Supt. of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond is considering a run for governor in 2026 after Gov. Gavin Newsom's term is up.
item.content:encoded: California Supt. of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond is considering a run for governor in 2026 after Gov. Gavin Newsom's term is up.

media:content.media:description: Tony Thurmond.

item.title: Here we go again: 'Intense heat wave' expected next week across Southern California
item.dc:creator: Grace Toohey
item.description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected by Wednesday in many parts of Southern and Central California. Even the coasts will feel significantly warmer.
item.content:encoded: Triple-digit temperatures are expected by Wednesday in many parts of Southern and Central California. Even the coasts will feel significantly warmer.

media:content.media:description: Huntington Beach, CA - July 04: Large crowds celebrate Independence Day after the Huntington Beach parade and before watching fireworks celebration over the ocean at the pier n in Huntington Beach Tuesday, July 4, 2023. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man found dead in his car in Death Valley National Park, an apparent heat victim
item.dc:creator: Summer Lin
item.description: A man was found dead in his car from apparent heat-related illness Monday in Death Valley National Park, according to authorities said.
item.content:encoded: A man was found dead in his car from apparent heat-related illness Monday in Death Valley National Park, according to authorities said.

media:content.media:description: DEATH VALLEY, CA - MARCH 3: Artists Drive is viewed at sunset on March 3, 2023, near Furnace Creek, California. Death Valley National Park, the largest park in the contiguous United States, straddling the border of California and Nevada, is also the hottest, driest and lowest park, dropping to 282 feet below sea level. (Photo by George Rose/Getty Images)

item.title: Future demand for wood will undermine efforts to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions
item.dc:creator: Tony Briscoe
item.description: As global demand for wood products is projected to rise over the coming decades, the world is expected to log about 3 million square miles of forestland.
item.content:encoded: As global demand for wood products is projected to rise over the coming decades, the world is expected to log about 3 million square miles of forestland.

media:content.media:description: SCOTIA, CA - APRIL 16: In Scotia, California, the Humbolt Redwood Company sawmill is not operating due to the coronavirus, but logging is still happening and trees are piling up in Scotia. Scotia on Thursday, April 16, 2020 in Scotia, CA. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Crosses set on fire outside Sylmar church in possible hate crime
item.dc:creator: Nathan Solis
item.description: Firefighters responded to initial reports of a rubbish fire in front of Sylmar Christian Fellowship Church. Three wooden crosses had been burned.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters responded to initial reports of a rubbish fire in front of Sylmar Christian Fellowship Church. Three wooden crosses had been burned.

media:content.media:description: SYLMAR, CA - JULY 06: Pastor Pierre Howard with one of three crosses found burning on the morning of Thursday, July 06, 2023, at Sylmar Christian Fellowship Church, Sylmar, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: High-stakes, high-stress college essay stirs more anxiety under affirmative action ban
item.dc:creator: Milla Surjadi, Howard Blume, Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The college essay, a crucial pitch in which applicants have limited words to describe who they are and why campuses should admit them, just got more stressful for students of color with the affirmative action ban.
item.content:encoded: The college essay, a crucial pitch in which applicants have limited words to describe who they are and why campuses should admit them, just got more stressful for students of color with the affirmative action ban.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - June 14: Simya Smith, Dorsey 11th grade, speaks while joining LAUSD students protesting, calling for an end to school police in front of the LAUSD School Police headquarters Tuesday, June 14, 2022. The LAUSD school board is likely to debate school police funding two short blocks away at district headquarters during the Tuesday board meeting. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After years of ups and downs, Los Angeles moves forward on creation of a public bank
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Kramon
item.description: The City Council voted to fund a feasibility study for a public bank in Los Angeles. Advocates say a public bank will better serve the community.
item.content:encoded: The City Council voted to fund a feasibility study for a public bank in Los Angeles. Advocates say a public bank will better serve the community.

media:content.media:description: Assemblyman Miguel Santiago, D-Los Angeles, left, presents Assemblyman David Chiu, D-San Francisco, third from left, a note reading #PUBLIC BANKS NOW after Chiu's measure to let California cities create their own public banks, was approved by the Assembly in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, Sept. 13, 2019. Assemblyman Jeff Stone, D-Scotts Valley, second from left, and Assemblyman Ash Kalra, D-San Jose, right, joined in on the celebration. The bill now goes to the governor. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Bay Area birdwatchers mourn the failed rescue of 'Tuffy,' the kidnapped baby hawk
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: The story of Tuffy, a baby red-tailed hawk who was kidnapped by a family of bald eagles, has come to a sad end following a failed rescue attempt.
item.content:encoded: The story of Tuffy, a baby red-tailed hawk who was kidnapped by a family of bald eagles, has come to a sad end following a failed rescue attempt.

item.title: 9th Circuit conservatives blast homelessness ruling, say issue is 'paralyzing' U.S. West
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Some of the most powerful conservative judges in the U.S. took aim at the idea that homeless people with nowhere else to go have a right to sleep in public.
item.content:encoded: Some of the most powerful conservative judges in the U.S. took aim at the idea that homeless people with nowhere else to go have a right to sleep in public.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 6, 2023 - Douglas Kaufman, 55, wipes his eyes on a sidewalk blocked with tents at a homeless encampment known as Skid Row West under the 405 freeway overpass along Venice Blvd. in Los Angeles on July 6, 2023. Beiard was referring to conservative members of the U.S. 9th Circuit Court of Appeals who took collective aim Wednesday at the idea that homeless people with nowhere else to go have a right to sleep in public, excoriating their liberal colleagues for ruling as much. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times) Attention Editors: Kaufman was not crying.

item.title: Tulare Lake's ghostly rebirth brings wonder — and hardship. Inside a community's resilience
item.dc:creator: Robert Gauthier, Melissa Gomez
item.description: Tulare Lake's rebirth will reshape life in the San Joaquin Valley for years to come. But longtime residents remain committed to the region and its remarkable seasonal rhythms.
item.content:encoded: Tulare Lake's rebirth will reshape life in the San Joaquin Valley for years to come. But longtime residents remain committed to the region and its remarkable seasonal rhythms.

media:content.media:description: Stratford, CA, Tuesday, May 2, 2023 - Farmers Charles Meyer Sr. and Charles Meyer Jr., survey the condition of a berm/road lining an irrigation channel near the Tulare Lake Canal. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After deputy throws woman to ground, Luna says probe will go beyond viral video
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Childs
item.description: L.A. County Sheriff Robert Luna addressed a physical altercation between a woman and a deputy outside a Lancaster grocery store seen in a body camera video.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County Sheriff Robert Luna addressed a physical altercation between a woman and a deputy outside a Lancaster grocery store seen in a body camera video.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - DECEMBER 14, 2022 - - L.A. County Sheriff Robert Luna, attends a press conference to discuss the dangers of counterfeit pharmaceuticals and the launch an innovative public awareness campaign using a PSA film titled, "Bad Meds," at the Hall of Justice on December 14, 2022. Actor Danny Trejo stars in the PSA film. Safe.Pharmacy created the PSA film aiming to combat deadly counterfeit medicine and drugs sold online. "Bad Meds," will run across TV, social media, radio, print and out-of-home. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Space shuttle Endeavour preps for move to vertical landing in new museum
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Lorena Iñiguez Elebee
item.description: To get ready for Endeavour's grand move, crews will begin installation of the base of the shuttle's full stack on July 20 at the new Samuel Oschin Air and Space Center.
item.content:encoded: To get ready for Endeavour's grand move, crews will begin installation of the base of the shuttle's full stack on July 20 at the new Samuel Oschin Air and Space Center.

media:content.media:description: A rendering of the space shuttle Endeavour, as it's expected to appear in the new Samuel Oschin Air and Space Center when it's completed.

item.title: Pioneering breast cancer surgeon Susan Love dies at 75
item.dc:creator: Corinne Purtill
item.description: Dr. Susan Love encouraged patients to take an active role in their care and created a comprehensive guide to breast cancer long before the internet.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Susan Love encouraged patients to take an active role in their care and created a comprehensive guide to breast cancer long before the internet.

media:content.media:description: Susan Love, center left, sits with Sarah Marshall, center right, William Goodson, right, and Shozo Ohsumi left, at a press briefing at the CTRC-AARC San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium at the Henry B. Gonzalez in San Antonio on Friday, Dec. 12, 2008. Love is the President of the Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation and the President of the Love/Avon Army of Women. (AP Photo/San Antonio Express-News, Lisa Krantz) ** RUMBO DE SAN ANTONIO OUT **

item.title: Babysitter charged with first-degree murder after toddler dies from head injury
item.dc:creator: Cari Spencer
item.description: Heather Greenman has been charged with murder after a toddler she was babysitting suffered a fatal head injury. She has pleaded not guilty.
item.content:encoded: Heather Greenman has been charged with murder after a toddler she was babysitting suffered a fatal head injury. She has pleaded not guilty.

media:content.media:description: Riverside, California-July 5, 2023-Heather Greenman, age 37, of Riverside, arrested for child abuse resulting in the death of a child. The investigation began on April 26, 2023, when the Beaumont Police Department was notified by the Riverside County Coroner's Office, of the death of a 15-month-old child, who had suffered a head-injury while in the custody of a babysitter. The babysitter, identified as Greenman, reported the child had fallen while running (Beaumont Police Department)

item.title: Child critically wounded by stray bullet during Fourth of July celebrations in South L.A.
item.dc:creator: Saumya Gupta
item.description: A 6-year-old boy was in critical condition after being struck by a stray bullet.
item.content:encoded: A 6-year-old boy was in critical condition after being struck by a stray bullet.

media:content.media:description: A six-year old boy is left in critical condition after he was shot by a stray bullet during the Fourth of July celebrations.

(Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. hotel workers are back on the job, but say more strikes are to come
item.dc:creator: Helen Li, Suhauna Hussain
item.description: Thousands of Southern California hotel workers were back on the job Wednesday after three days of strikes. Their union says more walkouts are ahead.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of Southern California hotel workers were back on the job Wednesday after three days of strikes. Their union says more walkouts are ahead.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - Picket signs of striking members of the Unite Here Local 11 hotel workers union partially obscure the sign of the JW Marriott Hotel in downtown Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023. The strike affects roughly 15,000 cooks, room attendants, dishwashers, servers, bellmen and front-desk agents at hotels in Los Angeles and Orange counties, July 03: in Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Are you two the token Black kids of the department?' The snubs and insults that accompanied affirmative action
item.dc:creator: Akiya Dillon, David Wharton
item.description: An unintended consequence of affirmative action — a policy meant to boost diversity — is that it can be wielded like a weapon to make people of color feel like they don't belong. The Times spoke with Black and Latino Americans who wonder if this stigma will persist.
item.content:encoded: An unintended consequence of affirmative action — a policy meant to boost diversity — is that it can be wielded like a weapon to make people of color feel like they don't belong. The Times spoke with Black and Latino Americans who wonder if this stigma will persist.

item.title: A Black LAPD officer wanted to make a difference. Then, he says, he was racially profiled by his own department
item.dc:creator: Libor Jany, Richard Winton
item.description: Bernard Robins, who was detained outside his parents' South L.A. home by fellow LAPD officers, said the episode typifies the style of biased policing that's practiced in some parts of the city.
item.content:encoded: Bernard Robins, who was detained outside his parents' South L.A. home by fellow LAPD officers, said the episode typifies the style of biased policing that's practiced in some parts of the city.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. SEP 21, 2022. Bernard Robins, a former Los Angeles police officer who was detained outside his South L.A. home by fellow LAPD officers, is publicly accusing some of his former colleagues of biased policing. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Opinion: We've got it all wrong about sequoias and wildfire
item.dc:creator: Chad Hanson
item.description: Managing the Sierra groves for low-intensity fire, and attempting to prevent and exclude higher-intensity fire, is like managing for the extinction of giant sequoias.
item.content:encoded: Managing the Sierra groves for low-intensity fire, and attempting to prevent and exclude higher-intensity fire, is like managing for the extinction of giant sequoias.

media:content.media:description: Abundant giant sequoia regeneration in high intensity fire patches In the Nelder Grove, a sequoia grove near Yosemite, burned in the Railroad fire in 2017. June 27, 2023. Credit Bryant Baker.

item.title: Photos: Fourth of July celebrations
item.dc:creator: Luis Sinco, Allen J. Schaben, Kent Nishimura, Wally Skalij
item.description: Photos of Fourth of July celebrations.
item.content:encoded: Photos of Fourth of July celebrations.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - Boys Scouts carry a huge American flag down Main Street during the Huntington Beach Independence Day Parade on July 4, 2023. Thousands of people gathered in the Orange County coastal community for the annual ecvent. July 04: in Los Angeles on Tuesday, July 4, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Disturbing': Sheriff's Department opens probe after deputy throws woman to the ground
item.dc:creator: Gabriel San Román
item.description: Both deputies who responded to the Lancaster robbery have been taken off field duty pending review, according to the L.A. County Sheriff's Department.
item.content:encoded: Both deputies who responded to the Lancaster robbery have been taken off field duty pending review, according to the L.A. County Sheriff's Department.

media:content.media:description: Officials with the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department released body-worn camera footage of a disturbing use of force incident in Lancaster that, according to a late Monday night announcement by the department, is currently under investigation. The confrontation happened on June 24 when deputies from the Lancaster Sheriff's Station responded to the parking lot of a WinCo Foods store, located at 740 W. Ave. K 4, on reports of an "in-progress robbery."

item.title: Man lighting fireworks in Wilmington street dies after being struck and dragged 85 feet
item.dc:creator: Gabriel San Román
item.description: A second driver also hit the man but remained at the scene of the hit-and-run in Wilmington.
item.content:encoded: A second driver also hit the man but remained at the scene of the hit-and-run in Wilmington.

media:content.media:description: Authorities are investigating after a fatal hit-and-run crash Monday night in Wilmington involving a man reportedly lighting off fireworks in the road. Officers with the Los Angeles Police Department responded to the scene, located at 710 N. Fries Avenue, near a Food 4 Less grocery store, at around 9:10 p.m. on reports of a vehicle hitting a pedestrian

item.title: 1 person killed and 3 injured in plane crash in Riverside County
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Jack Leonard
item.description: The crash was reported around 2 p.m. Tuesday near French Valley Airport in Riverside County.
item.content:encoded: The crash was reported around 2 p.m. Tuesday near French Valley Airport in Riverside County.

media:content.media:description: One person is dead and three others have been hospitalized after a plane went down in southwest Riverside County Tuesday afternoon. The single-engine Cessna 172 crashed just after 2 p.m. after taking off from the county-owned French Valley Airport near Murrieta.

item.title: Visiting L.A. during the hotel workers' strike? Here's what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Gisselle Medina, Emma Fox, Jon Healey
item.description: The walkout by Local 11 of Unite Here is affecting about 20 hotels. Although they are staying open, their guests can expect the hotels to be noisier and possibly trim the amenities.
item.content:encoded: The walkout by Local 11 of Unite Here is affecting about 20 hotels. Although they are staying open, their guests can expect the hotels to be noisier and possibly trim the amenities.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 2, 2023 - Hotel workers picket in front of the Sheraton Grand Hotel as members of Unite Here Local 11 joined dozens of other southland hotels who went on strike today in downtown Los Angeles on July 2, 2023. Hotel workers formed picket lines at many of the businesses in an effort to secure higher pay and improvements in health care and retirement benefits. The contract between the hotels and Unite Here Local 11 expired at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'They didn't deserve this': Venice wine store picks up the pieces after $600,000 heist
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Customers who entered Lincoln Fine Wines in Venice offered a sense of "normalcy" for owner Nazmul Haque after the theft.
item.content:encoded: Customers who entered Lincoln Fine Wines in Venice offered a sense of "normalcy" for owner Nazmul Haque after the theft.

media:content.media:description: A Venice Wine Store known as Lincoln Fine Wines was robbed on Friday night into Saturday morning overnight around midnight. The store owner, Nazmul Haque, estimates 60% of his inventory was stolen ranging from $500K to $600K. At least one thief broke through the roof and ransacked his cellar, where his most expensive wines were located.
media:content.media:credit: Nazmul Haque/Courtesy of Lincoln Fine Wines

item.title: L.A. mayor ousts Native American DWP commissioner; Indigenous groups outraged
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagún
item.description: The removal of a Native American on the Los Angeles Board of Water and Power Commissioners is 'a slap in the face,' Indigenous groups say.
item.content:encoded: The removal of a Native American on the Los Angeles Board of Water and Power Commissioners is 'a slap in the face,' Indigenous groups say.

media:content.media:description: Chatsworth, CA - December 21: Rudy Ortega Jr, left, Tribal President Fernandeno Tataviam Band of Mission Indians and Cynthia Ruiz VP of LADWP commissioner, present a shawl to Mayor Karen Bass, center, at Winter Solstice sunrise ceremony by leaders of the Tataviam Band of Mission Indians and community members at Chatsworth Nature Preserve on Wednesday, Dec. 21, 2022 in Chatsworth, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: At a South Pasadena adobe, a different way to remember the Fourth of July
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: The 180-year-old Adobe Flores in South Pasadena is one of the last remaining structures from the time that Southern California was part of Mexico.
item.content:encoded: The 180-year-old Adobe Flores in South Pasadena is one of the last remaining structures from the time that Southern California was part of Mexico.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH PASADENA, CA - JULY 01: Adobe Flores in South Pasadena was named in honor of Mexican Gen. Jose Maria Flores who met in this house to discuss a tentative treaty during the U.S.-Mexican war that became the Articles of Capitulation. About a year later, the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo ended the U.S.-Mexican war. The private residence is South Pasadena's first Cultural Heritage Landmark and is also included in the National Register of Historic Places. Photographed at Adobe Flores in South Pasadena, CA on Saturday, July 1, 2023. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Brushfire contained near Santa Clarita after threatening structures
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Childs
item.description: A grass fire burned over 14 acres north of Acton near Santa Clarita late Monday afternoon, according to the Los Angeles County Fire Department.
item.content:encoded: A grass fire burned over 14 acres north of Acton near Santa Clarita late Monday afternoon, according to the Los Angeles County Fire Department.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters attacked a grass fire that had burned at least 15 acres northeast of Santa Clarita late Monday afternoon, according to the Los Angeles County Fire Department. Dubbed the Peter fire, the incident was first reported shortly after 4 p.m. in the 3000 block of Dwight Lee Street.

item.title: After lawsuit, Jon & Vinny's adds explainer on customer checks about 18% service fee
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: After a class-action lawsuit was filed against Jon and Vinny's, the restaurant changed language regarding the 18% service fee on customer checks.
item.content:encoded: After a class-action lawsuit was filed against Jon and Vinny's, the restaurant changed language regarding the 18% service fee on customer checks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA. - JUNE 23, 2015: Exterior for Jonathan Gold food review of Jon & Vinny's in Los Angeles on June 23, 2015. (Anne Cusack/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: No sign of progress in L.A. hotel strike ahead of Fourth of July holiday
item.dc:creator: Suhauna Hussain, Helen Li, Julia Wick
item.description: Employees at 18 hotels — including the Biltmore and JW Marriott in downtown Los Angeles and the Fairmont Miramar in Santa Monica — have gone on strike, according to the union.
item.content:encoded: Employees at 18 hotels — including the Biltmore and JW Marriott in downtown Los Angeles and the Fairmont Miramar in Santa Monica — have gone on strike, according to the union.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - Striking members of the Unite Here Local 11 hotel workers union picket outside of the JW Marriott Hotel in downtown Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023. The strike affects roughly 15,000 cooks, room attendants, dishwashers, servers, bellmen and front-desk agents at hotels in Los Angeles and Orange counties, July 03: in Los Angeles on Monday, July 3, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fireworks and lunar glow: Supermoon to make appearance for Fourth of July
item.dc:creator: Christian Martinez
item.description: Fireworks will not be the only things lighting up the night sky this week, as the summer's first "supermoon" will rise Monday and stick around into the Fourth of July.
item.content:encoded: Fireworks will not be the only things lighting up the night sky this week, as the summer's first "supermoon" will rise Monday and stick around into the Fourth of July.

media:content.media:description: May 25: Clouds surround the supermoon in Joshua Tree National Park before a lunar eclipse May 25. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Poway man hid mother's death for 32 years, collected more than $800,000 in benefits
item.dc:creator: Salvador Hernandez
item.description: A Poway man admitted he hid his mother's death for more than 30 years and collected more than $830,000 in her benefits.
item.content:encoded: A Poway man admitted he hid his mother's death for more than 30 years and collected more than $830,000 in her benefits.

item.title: Cross at Christian camp in Orange County is found sawed down
item.dc:creator: Cari Spencer
item.description: The vandalized cross was found in the first week of Bible camp in Silverado Canyon. No campers were staying overnight at the time of the incident.
item.content:encoded: The vandalized cross was found in the first week of Bible camp in Silverado Canyon. No campers were staying overnight at the time of the incident.

media:content.media:description: A view of the 14-foot wooden cross at the Santiago Retreat Center before it was cut down. The cross was recently been dedicated during a retreat in mid June.

item.title: First heat wave of the summer bears down on SoCal. Antelope and Santa Clarita valleys hit triple digits
item.dc:creator: Summer Lin
item.description: Southern Californians should brace for another few days of high temperatures, as the first heat wave of the summer continues to bear down on the region.
item.content:encoded: Southern Californians should brace for another few days of high temperatures, as the first heat wave of the summer continues to bear down on the region.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - June 21: The sun is out as visitors walk past the Astronomers Monument at the Griffith Observatory on Wednesday, June 21, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Anti-cruelty law that gives pigs more space could raise ham, bacon prices
item.dc:creator: Noah Goldberg
item.description: New California law requiring pork farmers to give pigs enough room to turn around in their stalls finally takes effect.
item.content:encoded: New California law requiring pork farmers to give pigs enough room to turn around in their stalls finally takes effect.

media:content.media:description: A sow nurses her piglets inside a farrowing crate large enough for the animal to turn around on farm run by Jared Schilling Thursday, June 29, 2023, in Walsh, Ill. Schilling has made his farm compliant with a California law, taking effect on July 1, that promises to get breeding pigs out of narrow cages that restrict their movement. (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson)

item.title: Crews contain wildfires in Angeles National Forest north of Arcadia, Tujunga
item.dc:creator: Nathan Solis, Jeremy Childs
item.description: A wildfire in steep, rocky terrain in Angeles National Forest was fully contained Monday evening after scorching nearly 6 acres in the Santa Anita Canyon area.
item.content:encoded: A wildfire in steep, rocky terrain in Angeles National Forest was fully contained Monday evening after scorching nearly 6 acres in the Santa Anita Canyon area.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters were working to contain a slow moving Chantry fire burning in the Santa Anita Canyon in Arcadia on July 2.

item.title: Michael Neely, innovator and leader in L.A. homeless and drug treatment services, has died at age 74
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Neely, a Marine veteran of the Vietnam War, drew up the idea for Los Angeles' first homeless outreach team while living in a cardboard box on Skid Row.
item.content:encoded: Neely, a Marine veteran of the Vietnam War, drew up the idea for Los Angeles' first homeless outreach team while living in a cardboard box on Skid Row.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, California, 1998-Michael E. Neely photographed at Kedren Community Health in the Tom Bradley Auditorium, in Los Angeles, CA. The site is located at 4211 South Avalon Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90011 (Cheryl Branch)

item.title: As California fire season begins, debate over wildfire retardant heats up
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: While many fire experts say retardant is an invaluable resource for battling blazes, a growing number of environmentalists have raised concerns about the bright pink material.
item.content:encoded: While many fire experts say retardant is an invaluable resource for battling blazes, a growing number of environmentalists have raised concerns about the bright pink material.

media:content.media:description: CHINO HILLS, CA - OCTOBER 27: Air tanker makes fire retardant drop behind homes on Tuesday, Oct. 27, 2020 in Chino Hills, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Sorry, founders, we've never been created equal
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: The nation's founders declared that all men are created equal. It was a noble declaration of principles that had little resemblance to real life.
item.content:encoded: The nation's founders declared that all men are created equal. It was a noble declaration of principles that had little resemblance to real life.

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 29: Kashish Bastola, a rising sophomore at Harvard University speaks outside of the Supreme Court of the United States on Thursday, June 29, 2023 in Washington, DC. In a 6-3 vote, Supreme Court Justices ruled that race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina are unconstitutional, setting precedent for affirmative action in other universities and colleges. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom hits the road to campaign for Biden in Idaho, building his own base in red states
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wiley
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is on a campaign tour, stumping for President Biden in red states. And he's building his own voter base along the way.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is on a campaign tour, stumping for President Biden in red states. And he's building his own voter base along the way.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom is using his new political action committee to stump for Biden, while simultaneously building a national profile for himself.

item.title: Staff cuts, long commutes, rising costs: Hotel workers say they simply can't keep up
item.dc:creator: Helen Li, Suhauna Hussain
item.description: Clocking in for picketing that began as early as 6 a.m., hotel workers expressed determination — as well as nerves.
item.content:encoded: Clocking in for picketing that began as early as 6 a.m., hotel workers expressed determination — as well as nerves.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 2, 2023 - Hotel workers picket in front of the Intercontinental Hotel as members of Unite Here Local 11 joined dozens of other southland hotels who went on strike today in downtown Los Angeles on July 2, 2023. Hotel workers formed picket lines at many of the businesses in an effort to secure higher pay and improvements in health care and retirement benefits. The contract between the hotels and Unite Here Local 11 expired at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'It's a disaster': California farmer faces ordeal as pistachio farm sits underwater
item.dc:creator: Ian James
item.description: A California businessman invested his savings in a pistachio farm. The return of Tulare Lake has left hundreds of his acres underwater.
item.content:encoded: A California businessman invested his savings in a pistachio farm. The return of Tulare Lake has left hundreds of his acres underwater.

media:content.media:description: Corcoran, CA, Monday, June 5, 2023 - PG&E crews travel by airboat to decommission power poles on Makram Hanna's flooded pistachio orchard. A breach of the nearby Boyette Levee allowed water to flow from the surging Tulare Lake and flooded hundreds of acres owned by a conglomerate led by Hanna. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Magnitude 3.8 earthquake felt near Malibu
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake was reported at 2:29 a.m. Sunday 12 miles from Malibu, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake was reported at 2:29 a.m. Sunday 12 miles from Malibu, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.8 earthquake was reported 12 miles from Malibu early Sunday.

item.title: Chaos in Little Tokyo as customers run for cover from suspects in a high-speed chase
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Little Tokyo erupted in chaos Saturday evening as suspects in a high-speed chase abandoned their car and fled through a crowded plaza.
item.content:encoded: Little Tokyo erupted in chaos Saturday evening as suspects in a high-speed chase abandoned their car and fled through a crowded plaza.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MARCH 18, 2021: People visit Little Tokyo in downtown Los Angeles on Thursday, March 18, 2021. According to new data from the U.S. Census Bureau released Thursday, Aug. 12, 2021, California's Asian population grew by 25% in the past decade, making them the fastest growing ethnic group in the nation's most populous state(Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands of hotel workers across Southern California walk off the job
item.dc:creator: Helen Li, Suhauna Hussain, Susanne Rust, Hannah Fry
item.description: With hotels packed for the holiday weekend and the Anime Expo in full swing, a massive strike gets underway in Los Angeles and Orange counties.
item.content:encoded: With hotels packed for the holiday weekend and the Anime Expo in full swing, a massive strike gets underway in Los Angeles and Orange counties.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 2, 2023 - Hotel worker Martha Munoz uses the bullhorn while picketing in front of the Intercontinental Hotel as members of Unite Here Local 11 joined dozens of other southland hotels who went on strike today in downtown Los Angeles on July 2, 2023. Hotel workers formed picket lines at many of the businesses in an effort to secure higher pay and improvements in health care and retirement benefits. The contract between the hotels and Unite Here Local 11 expired at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Migrant fathers celebrate their day at a family shelter in Mexico with gifts and prayers
item.dc:creator: Raul Roa
item.description: Two U.S. groups came together to bring supplies and gifts to dads for Father's Day at a refugee shelter in Mexicali, Mexico.
item.content:encoded: Two U.S. groups came together to bring supplies and gifts to dads for Father's Day at a refugee shelter in Mexicali, Mexico.

media:content.media:description: Refugee Juan Carlos Manzo Manzo, right, grabs one of the gift bags each father received for Father's Day at refugee shelter Cobina Posada Del Migrante in Mexicali, Mexico, on Saturday, June 24, 2023. The shelter, five minutes from the Mexico/USA border, houses families who are waiting for their refugee applications to be processed in the United States.
media:content.media:credit: Raul Roa/Los Angeles Times en Espanol

item.title: Quirky Alhambra bridge house sells for $430,000 — $180,000 over asking price
item.dc:creator: Roger Vincent
item.description: The unusual location of the house and its comparatively modest $250,000 asking price drew national attention and hundreds of visitors when it hit the market a few weeks ago.
item.content:encoded: The unusual location of the house and its comparatively modest $250,000 asking price drew national attention and hundreds of visitors when it hit the market a few weeks ago.

item.title: Parts of the Southland under excessive heat warning with temperatures up to 108 expected
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Southern California is set to see its highest temperatures of the year this weekend as an oppressive heat wave blankets much of the state.
item.content:encoded: Southern California is set to see its highest temperatures of the year this weekend as an oppressive heat wave blankets much of the state.

media:content.media:description: LAKE BALBOA, CA-DECEMBER 28, 2022: Jamie Flores, 19, finds a nice place to sit and have lunch during a visit to Lake Balboa Park in Lake Balboa. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Another bus carrying dozens of migrants from Texas arrives at Union Station in downtown L.A.
item.dc:creator: Jack Herrera
item.description: Two weeks after a bus carrying 42 migrants pulled into Union Station, Texas has sent another bus to L.A.
item.content:encoded: Two weeks after a bus carrying 42 migrants pulled into Union Station, Texas has sent another bus to L.A.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Public Health officials cart away paperwork and other items after checking on about 50 migrants at St. Anthony's Croatian Church in Chinatown on Saturday July 1, 2023. A bus from Texas arrived for the second time in three weeks in Los Angeles with about 50 migrants.

item.title: Makeshift RV park stirs controversy in Sylmar. But is it a hazard or a help?
item.dc:creator: Brennon Dixson, Rachel Uranga
item.description: The Los Angeles city attorney's office charged the owner of the home with two misdemeanors, but some tenants argue she is helping people with nowhere else to go.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles city attorney's office charged the owner of the home with two misdemeanors, but some tenants argue she is helping people with nowhere else to go.

media:content.media:description: Residents are concerned over an illegal, makeshift RV park behind a Sylmar home, with some saying the unsanitary conditions are posing major safety concerns. The residence is zoned as a single-family home which neighbors said is not meant to accommodate such a large number of people. Located on the 14000 block of Hubbard Street in Sylmar.

item.title: Copper wire thefts on the rise, causing delays for Metro's rail lines
item.dc:creator: Saumya Gupta
item.description: A surge of thefts of valuable copper wiring has caused disruptions for the Metro rail system, which serves more than 5 million riders a month.
item.content:encoded: A surge of thefts of valuable copper wiring has caused disruptions for the Metro rail system, which serves more than 5 million riders a month.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - APRIL 13: A conductor boards a metro car at the Blue Line Metro 1st Street station in downtown on Thursday, April 13, 2023 in Long Beach, CA. People using the Blue Line Metro station where a man was stabbed to death on April 12th at the 1st Street station around 3:38 p.m. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: West Hollywood will have the nation's highest minimum wage. Business owners are not happy
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Many low-wage workers in West Hollywood will see a pay increase on Saturday as the city's minimum jumps to $19.08 an hour.
item.content:encoded: Many low-wage workers in West Hollywood will see a pay increase on Saturday as the city's minimum jumps to $19.08 an hour.

media:content.media:description: West Hollywood, CA - June 29: Lucian Tudor, CEO of Global Dining, Inc of CA., is photographed in the main dining room of La Boheme, in West Hollywood, CA, Thursday, June 29, 2023. Tudor has spoken out about the financial stress West Hollywood's increase to the minimum wage, on July 1 to $19.09 has caused his restaurant on Santa Monica Blvd. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A question for Asian Americans celebrating affirmative action's end: What have we won?
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: Affirmative action's end is celebrated by some Asian Americans, but what have we won? And what have we lost?
item.content:encoded: Affirmative action's end is celebrated by some Asian Americans, but what have we won? And what have we lost?

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 29: People with the Asian American Coalition for Education rally outside of the Supreme Court of the United States on Thursday, June 29, 2023 in Washington, DC. In a 6-3 vote, Supreme Court Justices ruled that race-conscious admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina are unconstitutional, setting precedent for affirmative action in other universities and colleges. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tens of thousands of L.A. County residents could soon lose Medi-Cal coverage. Here's why
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: The tentative figures are an early sign of the serious shift underway as the federal government has rolled back rules that helped people stay on Medicaid.
item.content:encoded: The tentative figures are an early sign of the serious shift underway as the federal government has rolled back rules that helped people stay on Medicaid.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-APRIL 14, 2023: Valerie Ibarra-Figueroa, left, a health insurance specialist at the Venice Family Clinic, talks on the phone to an employee at the department of public social services on behalf of Jessica Sanchez, 33, while helping get her medicaid coverage reinstated. Sanchez's medicaid coverage was wrongfully terminated on February 1, 2023. She is 31 weeks pregnant. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Is your local pool closed? Here's why — and how to find an alternative
item.dc:creator: Emma Fox
item.description: A lifeguard shortage has scrambled the hours and schedules at many L.A.-area public pools. Here's how to find a different pool — or become a lifeguard and earn a little summer cash.
item.content:encoded: A lifeguard shortage has scrambled the hours and schedules at many L.A.-area public pools. Here's how to find a different pool — or become a lifeguard and earn a little summer cash.

media:content.media:description: CARLSBAD, CA- JUNE 30, 2022: Senior lifeguard Ravelle Morales, 28, keeps an eye on swimmers at Monroe Street Pool on June 30, 2022 in Carlsbad, California. Morales has been lifeguarding for 9 years. There is a lifeguard shortage in California. Right now, there is a new bill AB 1672 that would allow ocean lifeguards to work at public pools amidst this shortage.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Two years after LAPD fireworks explosion, residents are still trying to rebuild
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Some residents are still living in a hotel downtown. Others have moved more than once. Life has been tough since a botched fireworks detonation blew up their South L.A. neighborhood.
item.content:encoded: Some residents are still living in a hotel downtown. Others have moved more than once. Life has been tough since a botched fireworks detonation blew up their South L.A. neighborhood.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 04: Some homes have plywood covering window and door openings on East 27th Street following the LAPD's fireworks explosion before the 4th of July. Homes and property on the the block of East 27th Street between Stanford Avenue and San Pedro Street were damaged by the LAPD's fireworks detonation that displaced more than 70 people. E. 27th Street and Stanford Avenue on Wednesday, Aug. 4, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: 'Like sitting on the 101 in L.A.': Yosemite visitors wait in line for hours to enter park
item.dc:creator: Cari Spencer
item.description: Car lines out of Yosemite National Park have been at a standstill this summer as visitors, employees and locals report long waits to enter the park.
item.content:encoded: Car lines out of Yosemite National Park have been at a standstill this summer as visitors, employees and locals report long waits to enter the park.

media:content.media:description: Yosemite National Park, CA - April 28: A few people stop by the patio at the 95-year-old Ahwahnee Hotel on Friday, April 28, 2023, in Yosemite National Park, CA. They relax briefly on the nearly empty patio. The hotel has been undergoing structural enhancements starting in January 2023 to complete seismic upgrades. Today, a closure alert on the Ahwahnee Hotel's website states that most of Yosemite Valley will be closed from 4/28 - 5/3 due to forecasted flooding. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Their love story ended in a mass shooting. Their families are still trying to pick up the pieces
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Arredondo
item.description: Two women killed in a shooting at the Beyond Wonderland music festival in Washington were from Southern California. They had just become engaged and moved to Seattle.
item.content:encoded: Two women killed in a shooting at the Beyond Wonderland music festival in Washington were from Southern California. They had just become engaged and moved to Seattle.

item.title: L.A. approves $860,000 settlement for man wounded by police during 2020 protest
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, David Zahniser
item.description: Los Angeles has agreed to pay $860,000 to settle claims from a protester that his rights were violated when he was shot with a police projectile in 2020.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles has agreed to pay $860,000 to settle claims from a protester that his rights were violated when he was shot with a police projectile in 2020.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - DECEMBER 08: Deon Jones, 29, a man who was shot in the face and badly injured by a LAPD projectile round during protests this summer and is now suing the city, photographed at his apartment in downtown, on Tuesday, Dec. 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times) **Story is embargoed until the lawsuit is filed Wednesday, 12/9, so photos should not post before story.**

item.title: L.A. air the 'cleanest' it's been in a decade, but rising temperatures could change that
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Arredondo
item.description: Greater Los Angeles has long carried the title of nation's smoggiest metropolitan area, but a stubborn marine layer and cooler temperatures brought some clarity this spring and summer.
item.content:encoded: Greater Los Angeles has long carried the title of nation's smoggiest metropolitan area, but a stubborn marine layer and cooler temperatures brought some clarity this spring and summer.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - April 19: A person looks out onto the downtown landscape from Montecito Heights on Wednesday, April 19, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Civil rights groups rally against union lawsuit to block deputy gang investigation
item.dc:creator: Keri Blakinger
item.description: The sheriff deputy union sued to keep members from having to show alleged gang tattoos. At a hearing in the case, civil rights advocates protested.
item.content:encoded: The sheriff deputy union sued to keep members from having to show alleged gang tattoos. At a hearing in the case, civil rights advocates protested.

media:content.media:description: Members of the LASD deputy gang known as the Executioners are alleged to sport tattoos of a skull with Nazi imagery and an AK-47, while members of the Banditos are allegedly known for their matching tattoos of a skeleton outfitted with a sombrero, bandoleer and pistol.

item.title: LAPD officer faulted in 2022 shooting of unarmed man in Leimert Park
item.dc:creator: Libor Jany
item.description: An LAPD sergeant broke department policy when he fired at a man from inside his moving police cruiser. The victim was holding a car part that the officer mistook for a gun.
item.content:encoded: An LAPD sergeant broke department policy when he fired at a man from inside his moving police cruiser. The victim was holding a car part that the officer mistook for a gun.

media:content.media:description: A man is loaded into an ambulance after being shot by police Monday, July 18, 2022, in Leimert Park near Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and South Bronson Avenue.

item.title: Transformer explodes at Warner Bros. studios in Burbank, causing brief fire
item.dc:creator: Christian Martinez, Ruben Vives, Jeremy Childs
item.description: At least two nearby buildings were evacuated after a blown transformer sparked an electrical fire. No injuries were reported, and the blaze was quickly extinguished.
item.content:encoded: At least two nearby buildings were evacuated after a blown transformer sparked an electrical fire. No injuries were reported, and the blaze was quickly extinguished.

media:content.media:description: View of smoke rising from the Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank taken from 5th floor of the nearby iHeartMedia building.

item.title: How many youth football players have six-figure deals? A 9-year-old in Snoop Dogg's league does
item.dc:creator: Chuck Schilken
item.description: Third-grader Ghalee Wadood Jr. landed a six-figure NIL deal after a stellar season in Snoop Dogg's youth football league. His father says it will prepare him for life beyond the game.
item.content:encoded: Third-grader Ghalee Wadood Jr. landed a six-figure NIL deal after a stellar season in Snoop Dogg's youth football league. His father says it will prepare him for life beyond the game.

media:content.media:description: Ghalee Wadood Jr., a rising third grader at 54th Street Elementary in View Park, has signed a six-figure NIL deal with the Family 4 Life sports and entertainment agency.

item.title: For sale: San Francisco Art Institute campus, $50-million Diego Rivera mural included
item.dc:creator: Salvador Hernandez
item.description: The financially troubled San Francisco Art Institute is selling its campus, including its Diego Rivera mural, to help pay off $20 million in debts.
item.content:encoded: The financially troubled San Francisco Art Institute is selling its campus, including its Diego Rivera mural, to help pay off $20 million in debts.

media:content.media:description: "The Making of a Fresco Showing the Building of a City" painted by Diego Rivera in 1931 sits in a private gallery at San Francisco Art Institute in San Francisco, Calif. Wednesday, July 20, 2022. The mural recently underwent restoration, but the gallery is closed indefinitely along with the school which recently announced its permanent closure. (Jessica Christian/San Francisco Chronicle via AP)

item.title: Imelda Padilla claims victory in Valley council race
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Imelda Padilla declared victory Friday in the race for the L.A. City Council seat in the San Fernando Valley formerly held by Nury Martinez.
item.content:encoded: Imelda Padilla declared victory Friday in the race for the L.A. City Council seat in the San Fernando Valley formerly held by Nury Martinez.

media:content.media:description: Sun Valley, CA - June 27: LA City Council District 6 special election candidate Imelda Padilla speaks to supporters at her election party at Chicuagle in Sun Valley Tuesday, June 27, 2023. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave hits Southern California with a scorching Fourth of July weekend
item.dc:creator: Grace Toohey, Hayley Smith
item.description: After months of persistently overcast skies and cooler conditions, Southern and Central California are set to see some of their highest temperatures of the year.
item.content:encoded: After months of persistently overcast skies and cooler conditions, Southern and Central California are set to see some of their highest temperatures of the year.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA-APRIL 28, 2023: Ben Rodriguez cools off with a bottle of water after exercising horses for a customer in Glendale on Friday afternoon. Highs for much of Southern California will peak Saturday as the state braces for the warmest temperatures so far this year. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: CSU campuses have largely failed to repatriate Native remains and artifacts, auditor finds
item.dc:creator: Noah Goldberg
item.description: The CSU system has repatriated just 6% of its collections to tribes, the report found.
item.content:encoded: The CSU system has repatriated just 6% of its collections to tribes, the report found.

media:content.media:description: The clocktower infront of the library at SSU

item.title: Judge denies new trial for Mark Ridley-Thomas, upholds guilty verdict
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: The decision is a major legal setback for Ridley-Thomas and sets the stage for him to be sentenced later this summer. He faces the prospect of years in prison.
item.content:encoded: The decision is a major legal setback for Ridley-Thomas and sets the stage for him to be sentenced later this summer. He faces the prospect of years in prison.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - March 27: L.A. City Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas leaves court for the day at the Federal Courthouse on Monday, March 27, 2023 in Los Angeles, CA. He is accused of steering lucrative county contracts to USC's social work school in exchange for a slate of benefits for his son. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Planning a road trip this weekend? California gas tax hike will make July 4 travel more expensive
item.dc:creator: Summer Lin
item.description: Gas prices are expected to go up by 4 cents this weekend as part of the state gas tax, which increases every July to pay for roads and adjust for inflation.
item.content:encoded: Gas prices are expected to go up by 4 cents this weekend as part of the state gas tax, which increases every July to pay for roads and adjust for inflation.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-FEBRUARY 16, 2023: Angel Contreras purchases gas in Chinatown on Thursday, February 16, 2023. The average price of a gallon of self-serve regular gasoline in LA County is up today for the 15th consecutive day. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How to protect your dog from its worst enemy: Fourth of July fireworks
item.dc:creator: Emma Fox
item.description: Dogs and cats are often frightened by loud Fourth of July fireworks. Here's what to do if your pet is showing signs of stress before, during and after the fireworks.
item.content:encoded: Dogs and cats are often frightened by loud Fourth of July fireworks. Here's what to do if your pet is showing signs of stress before, during and after the fireworks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - JULY 4, 2022. Illegal fireworks explode over downtown Los Angeles on the Fourth of July. (Luis Sinco / os Angeles Times)

item.title: Robert Rivas sworn in as California Assembly speaker after long fight for power
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall, Hannah Wiley
item.description: By taking over as Assembly speaker, Robert Rivas becomes the first rural Californian in a generation to hold the powerful post in the state Capitol.
item.content:encoded: By taking over as Assembly speaker, Robert Rivas becomes the first rural Californian in a generation to hold the powerful post in the state Capitol.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO CA JUNE 30, 2023 - Assemblymember Robert Rivas is sworn into office as Assembly Speaker at the State Capitol in Sacramento, California on June 30, 2023. (Max Whittaker/For The Times)

item.title: 'Top shot' LAPD officer posts wedding photos holding semiautomatic weapon amid lawsuit against chief
item.dc:creator: Noah Goldberg
item.description: Officer Toni McBride showed off her JW3 TTI MPX Taran Tactical 9mm alongside her husband and bridal party at the wedding in photos posted Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Officer Toni McBride showed off her JW3 TTI MPX Taran Tactical 9mm alongside her husband and bridal party at the wedding in photos posted Thursday.

media:content.media:description: LAPD officer Toni McBride.

item.title: UC Berkeley graduate student gunned down on research trip to Mexico
item.dc:creator: Nathan Solis
item.description: Gabriel Trujillo, 31, went missing this month while collecting plant samples in the Mexican state of Sonora, his family said. He was found dead last week.
item.content:encoded: Gabriel Trujillo, 31, went missing this month while collecting plant samples in the Mexican state of Sonora, his family said. He was found dead last week.

media:content.media:description: In a photo provided by Roxanne Cruz-de Hoyos, Gabriel Trujillo conducts field research for his doctorate in Arizona. His research across North America was tragically cut short last week in Mexico, where Trujillo's father says he was shot seven times. Authorities discovered his body on June 22 in the state of Sonora, in northwest Mexico — days after his fiancée reported him missing. (Roxanne Cruz-de Hoyos via AP)

item.title: Crushed student loan borrowers are skipping meals, moving in with parents, panicking over money
item.dc:creator: Debbie Truong, Milla Surjadi, Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Student loan holders are bracing for a double hit. Biden's loan relief plan is blocked, and a years-long pandemic pause in payments ends in October.
item.content:encoded: Student loan holders are bracing for a double hit. Biden's loan relief plan is blocked, and a years-long pandemic pause in payments ends in October.

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 30: D'Aungilique Jackson, of Fresno, CA holds a "Cancel Student Debt" sign outside of the Supreme Court of the United States after the nation's high court stuck down President Biden's student debt relief program on Friday, June 30, 2023 in Washington, DC. In a 6-3 decision the Supreme Court stuck down the Biden administration's student debt forgiveness program in Biden v. Nebraska. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hip-hop pioneer Melle Mel arrested on suspicion of domestic violence
item.dc:creator: Jonah Valdez
item.description: Rap pioneer Melle Mel was arrested this week in downtown Los Angeles on a domestic violence charge after attending the BET Awards.
item.content:encoded: Rap pioneer Melle Mel was arrested this week in downtown Los Angeles on a domestic violence charge after attending the BET Awards.

media:content.media:description: Melle Mel poses backstage at the Grammy Nominations Concert on Wednesday, Nov. 30, 2011 in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello)

item.title: What should borrowers do now that Biden's college debt forgiveness plan is dead?
item.dc:creator: Jon Healey
item.description: The Supreme Court has ruled against the Biden administration's blanket college loan forgiveness plan, denying debtors the instant relief the program offered. But they still have better options for managing their debt than they did before the court took up the case.
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court has ruled against the Biden administration's blanket college loan forgiveness plan, denying debtors the instant relief the program offered. But they still have better options for managing their debt than they did before the court took up the case.

media:content.media:description: Student debt relief advocates gather outside the Supreme Court on Capitol Hill in Washington, Monday, Feb. 27, 2023, ahead of arguments over President Joe Biden's student debt relief plan. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky)

item.title: See which California counties are the most expensive for renters in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Terry Castleman
item.description: Northern California was deemed especially unaffordable for renters, with some Southern California counties also topping the list of least affordable places in America.
item.content:encoded: Northern California was deemed especially unaffordable for renters, with some Southern California counties also topping the list of least affordable places in America.

media:content.media:description: The "Painted Ladies" Victorian homes are seen at sunset in San Francisco, California, United States on October 18, 2021. The median sale price for a San Francisco Bay Area home in August 2021 is $1.26 million. (Photo by Yichuan Cao/Sipa USA)(Sipa via AP Images)

item.title: 'Killer' parties? Orcas making Central California coast their playground this summer
item.dc:creator: Salvador Hernandez
item.description: It's not uncommon to see killer whales along the California coast, but there have been more sightings than usual this month — including a huge group of 30.
item.content:encoded: It's not uncommon to see killer whales along the California coast, but there have been more sightings than usual this month — including a huge group of 30.

media:content.media:description: Killer whales tossed shearwaters into the air during an encounter in Monterey Bay on June 20.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of Patricia VanOver Indictor / Monterey Bay Whale Watch
